newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore details tax for life insurance surplus.
newsitem.headline: Singapore details tax for life insurance surplus.

text.p: The Singapore government has detailed its tax concession for life insurance surplus attributable to policyholders, the daily Straits Times newspaper said on Monday.

According to the government gazette published last Friday, it would impose a concessionary rate of 10 percent on life insurance surplus of any life insurance fund which is payable to policyholders, the ST said.
It said the new regulation also gave the formula for determining the policyholders' portion of the surplus for tax purposes.
The concession takes effect from year of assessment 1993.

The government had proposed in its Budget in 1992 that life insurance companies be taxed on their total income derived from business transactions in Singapore. This would include premiums collected as well as investment income. Previously only investment income was taxed.
It also proposed that the surplus be taxed at 10 percent on the portion attributable to policyholders, and at the prevailing corporate tax rate on the portion allotted to shareholders.
